B003X2O6KW|5.0|Let's get it out of the way up front: If you even tangentially follow the hip hop blogosphere or Twitterverse, you've heard almost all of the substantive tracks on this album (two of the 13 tracks are an interlude and outro). Fully five of the 11 songs were part of Kanye's G.O.O.D. Fridays scheme, another three leaked months ahead of the album's release, and \\"Dark Fantasy\\" was included in Kanye's recent short film. But does it matter? Maybe Kanye's done the impossible and crafted an album so good that we'll pay for it even when he gives it away for free.     After listening to the record you'll appreciate how succinctly the album's title summarizes its themes. The record is framed as a fairy tale and the first few lines (\\"The watered down one, the one you know/ Was made up centuries ago...Twisted fiction, sick addiction/ Gather around children, zip it, listen) almost allude to the gradual censorship of the Brothers Grimm's dark fairytales over the centuries. On My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, Kanye seeks to dismantle the facade of fame and fortune to reveal the twisted debauchery underneath.    Kanye's trademark arrogance is in full force on this album. But this time it's an unapologetic arrogance that's a product of being treated like a god on earth. On \\"Devil in a New Dress\\" he rhymes \\"It's hard to be humble when you're stuntin' on a jumbotron\\" and on \\"POWER\\" \\"I embody every characteristic of the egotisic, he knows he's so gifted.\\" The occult is another central theme, not only in track titles like \\"Devil in a New Dress,\\" \\"Monster\\" and \\"Hell of a Life\\" but in the bars on each record. Kanye offers \\"We headed to hell, for heaven's sake huh?/ Well I'mma levitate and make the devil wait, yeah.\\"     Perhaps the most personal theme on the album is a feeling of dissatisfaction in the face of so much commercial and critical success. We hear it on  \\"Runaway\\" (\\"I always find something wrong/ You've been putting up with me just way too long/I'm so gifted at finding what Idon't like the most\\"). And while Kanye keeps up the pretense of ego (see above) it's clear that the endless criticism has forced chinks in his armor. There are unveiled jabs at both Saturday Night Live and South Park, and bars including \\"It's not funny anymore, try different jokes,\\" and \\"I was lookin' at my resume, feelin' real fresh today/ But they rewrite history, I don't believe in yesterday.\\"       In short, the album is brilliant. The rhymes are clever, the music is rich, the emotions are raw and the themes are dark. My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy will be an interesting experiment in an age of dwindling album sales ostensibly due to piracy. If Kanye can move 800,000 units in his first week despite having given the album away, the power of good music will be proven and artists will have no one to blame but themselves.
B004BSIJ9Q|5.0|Even though Kanye gave away most of the Album free it feels great to support a great artist. I bought real CD Itunes and Amazon Digital. Great Album keep putting out G.O.O.D music Kanye
B003Z9Q4WG|5.0|At long, long last, SONY-CBS  has released its LEONARD BERNSTEIN SYMPHONY EDITION, following at least a good month and a half postponement from its originally scheduled date!<br /><br />The release of this CBS-Sony box set to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the maestro's passing in 1990 promises to be a generous feast of sixty compact discs.  What immediately comes to my mind here as a haunting reminder is the thirty eight DG Herbert von Karajan SYMPHONIES EDITION, released to commemorate the centennial anniversary of that conductor's birth year 2008, in 2009.  That set included complete symphony cycles of Beethoven, Bruckner, Brahms, Schumann, Mendelssohn, and Tchaikovsky, together with Haydn's six \\"Paris\\" and twelve \\"London\\" Symphonies, together with Mozart's 32, \\"Haffner,\\" \\"Linz,\\" \\"Prague,\\" the great Nos. 39, 40, and \\"Jupiter.\\"  All of these DG recordings do not quite approach the width and depth of Bernstein in their box.  DG released a complete HvK Edition of some 200 discs in Japan, of all places.  I cannot imagine why they did not make a wider, more global circulation.  Also, to mark that event, there were two EMI mega boxes released to commemorate HvK on 160 discs: an orchestral box and an operas box.<br /><br />Many of the recordings included in this comprehensive Lenny box are recordings upon which I can be said to have \\"cut my classical music teeth\\" back in the late 60s-early 1970s with their original LP record incarnations.  Back then,  I devoured the Mahler, Franck, Nielsen, Sibelius, Tchaikovsky, and the Schumann.  Particularly memorable were the Haydn \\"Paris\\" Symphonies, which even until and through this day, despite all manner of digital sound reproduction technique, I would stand Lenny's renditions of them, all of them, up against anyone else`s here.  I look forward to reacquainting myself with the re mastered Shostakovich SEVENTH.<br /><br />In this box set, among the more than one hundred symphonies offered and packaged here are complete cycles of Beethoven, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Sibelius, Schumann, Haydn's \\"Paris\\" and Londons,\\" as well as the very beloved cutting edge Mahler.<br /><br />Unlike previously earlier abortive Sony-CBS attempts to capitalize on the Leonard Bernstein stamp with the \\"Prince of Wales\\" sponsorship and \\"Bernstein Century\\" recordings, recordings which were served up in single releases at close to full price to induce if not force and compel Bernstein fans to buy into him once again, I hope this edition is the promise of more comprehensive work to come, like vocal music.  I look forward with eager anticipation to a prospective companion choral works box set with such gems as Lenny's rendition of Bach's ST. MATTHEW PASSION as well as his unique rendition of MESSIAH.  We can only hope....<br /><br />The below is the complete list of recordings from the box:<br /><br />Beethoven:  Symphonies 1-9 (Complete)<br /><br />Berlioz: Symphony Fantastique<br /><br />Bernstein: Symphonies 1-3 (Complete)<br /><br />Bizet: Symphony in C<br /><br />Blitzstein: The Airborne Symphony<br /><br />Brahms: Symphonies 1-4 (Complete)<br /><br />Bruckner: Symphony No. 9<br /><br />Copland: Symphony for Organ and Orchestra, 3<br /><br />Dvorak:  Symphonies 7, 8, and 9<br /><br />Franck:  Symphony in D Minor<br /><br />Goldmark:  Rustic Wedding Symphony<br /><br />Harris:  Symphony No.3<br /><br />Haydn:  Symphonies 82-88;  93-104<br /><br />Hindemith:  Symphony in E-Flat<br /><br />Ives:  Symphonies 2 and 3<br /><br />Liszt:  Faust Symphony<br /><br />Mahler: Symphonies 1-9 (Complete)<br /><br />Mendelssohn: Symphonies 3, 4, and 5<br /><br />Mozart: Symphonies 35, 36, 39, 40, and 41<br /><br />Nielsen:  Symphonies 2, 3, 4, and 5<br /><br />Prokofiev: Symphonies 1 and 5<br /><br />St. Saens:  Symphony No. 3<br /><br />Schubert:  Symphonies 5, 8, and 9<br /><br />Schumann:  Symphonies 1-4 (Complete)<br /><br />Schuman:  Symphonies 3, 5, and 8<br /><br />Shapero:  Symphony for Classical Orchestra<br /><br />Stravinsky:  Symphony of Psalms<br /><br />Shostakovich:  Symphonies 1, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 14<br /><br />Sibelius: Symphonies 1-7  (Complete)<br /><br />Tchaikovsky:  Symphonies 1-6 (Complete)<br /><br />Thompson: Symphony No. 2<br /><br />Vaughan-Williams:  Symphony No. 4>Stravinsky:  Symphony of Psalms<br /><br />Shostakovich:  Symphonies 1, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 14<br /><br />Sibelius: Symphonies 1-7  (Complete)<br /><br />Tchaikovsky:  Symphonies 1-6 (Complete)<br /><br />Thompson: Symphony No. 2<br /><br />Vaughan-Williams:  Symphony No. 4

0307473465|4.0|After seeing the movie, I was looking forward to reading the book to tie up some large loose ends.  While the book was more insightful, I was still left with unanswered questions and no real sense of closure.    The story takes place 30 years or so in post World War II Germany and uses the Holocaust as the backdrop for a plot that centers around a passionate and yet mysterious love affair between an attractive 36 year old woman, Hanna Schmitz who befriends a 15 year boy, Michael Berg on the way home from school when he falls ill.  Michael is soon bewitched by the older woman and an obsessive love affair blossoms. Hanna delights in being read aloud to from various literature classics that Michael is studying in high school and over time this becomes something of a ritual that unites the two. As their relationship deepens, however, he is puzzled by her bouts of moodiness and at times secretiveness.  Some months later, Hanna abruptly and mysteriously quits her job and leaves town with no word of where or why she has gone.      Flash forward 10 years and Michael, a law student, is assigned to attend a local trial of 5 woman charged as Nazi war criminals, accused of unspeakable crimes against prisoners while serving as prison guards at a Nazi death camp.  Much to his horror, Michael discovers that Hanna is one of the defendants.  However, during the trial, he also discovers a secret that Hanna has been hiding for years that may explain, although not condone, her behavior as a prison guard and as his lover.    What follows is a deep psychological exploration by Michael into the motives and drives behind both those who participated in the Holocaust and those who committed no atrocities and yet passively turned a blind eye to the crimes both during and after the war.      Although the plot is very good, I never really learned why the primary characters failed to act or speak up at crucial times when doing so could have easily lessened the burdens that haunted them.  While many may argue that this was precisely the message of the book I still found the lengths to which this occurred to be unreasonable given the specifics the story provides, especially with regards to Michael's inactions later in the book.  I felt like the story could have been much more satisfying had the author provided more insight into what Hanna was truly thinking and feeling as well as why Michael failed to make more of an effort to understand Hanna rather than just lamely guess at why she acted the way she did.
B00000K2VZ|5.0|Pearl,\\" (1971), is one of the most legendary of recordings.  It was, sadly, posthumously released, as Janis Joplin, its greatly-talented maker, died of a heroin overdose on October 4, 1970, at the age of 27, as she was finishing it up.  She left her vocal to \\"Buried Alive in the Blues\\" unsung; so that it was released on the record as an instrumental by Full-Tilt Boogie, the backing band she'd put together for herself, which most people preferred to Big Brother and the Holding Company, the San Francisco-based psychedelic blues rock band with which she first became popular.<br /><br />\\"Pearl\\" is bluesy, funky, driving, much like its troubled maker, and will have to stand as her memorial.  It has powerful tracks of \\"Cry Baby,\\" and a live \\"Try (Just a Little Bit Harder,\\" and a witty acapella \\"Mercedes Benz.\\"  \\"A Woman Left Lonely,\\" and Bobby Womack's \\"Trust Me,\\" are gritty blues.  \\"A Woman Left Lonely,\\" was, I believe, described by Time magazine as music to which a girl might cut her wrists.  Kris Kristofferson's \\"Me and Bobby McGee,\\" of course, became her signature song: it was her only number one hit, achieved posthumously.<br /><br />I actually was once able to see Janis live, with \\"Big Brother,\\" performing the [[ASIN:B00000K2VU Cheap Thrills (Exp)]] repertory, at a famous venue of the time, Bill Graham's Fillmore East, on New York's Lower East Side.  All these years later, I still remember the expectant hush when the house lights went down, the sweet aroma of various illegal substances, and Joplin's electrifying performance.  It was quite a night, I can tell you.  Nobody will ever have that chance again, but the recordings remain.
B0044KU7KU|5.0|When I originally heard \\"Na Na Na\\", I was afraid that this album would be their downfall. The song grew on me over time and now it is one of my favorite tracks. Then \\"Sing\\" came out and it was the same reaction again...\\"uh oh.\\" I didn't know what to expect when I bought this, but I decided to give them chance since I do love the past three albums. I am very happy to say that this record is amazing. Danger Days may not be as strong as their previous album, but it could just be that I haven't listened to it long enough for it to be up there. Still, I really do recommend this album to all of the MCR fans. This is one of the best albums of the year. It didn't let me down like others have this year.

B0043ZDU1E|5.0|\\"The Wind That Shakes the Barley\\" is a wonderful exploration and presentation of modern Celtic music. These nine songs are exceptionally well crafted and reflective of a truly skilled musician who explores the depths and richness of Celtic music. A soulful and fine presentation by this gifted artist.

Rick Deckard (Ford) is a retired detective, or as the title suggests \\"Blade Runner\\" who is hired once again to hunt down several rampant Replicants. B0034G4P7G|5.0|The last time I was in the movie theater I saw a preview for The Social Network and immediately put its opening date in my calendar. Now it's opening weekend and I already rushed to my nearest screening to see the movie about the website that has defined my generation. For those of you reading this out there...drop your computers, turn off your Blackberries, silence your iPhones and run to your nearest theater to see this film. Whether the story presented in the movie is 100% truthful, who knows. And honestly, who cares!    As some may know, Mark Zuckerberg created Facebook during his sophomore year at Harvard University with the help of his best friend Eduardo Saverin (you can look them up on facebook.com). The movie presents Zuckerberg as being a loner with few friends who wants desperately to be a part of the Pheonix Club on campus. When the popular crew team twins, Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, approach Zuckerberg about making a social connection website for Harvard students, Zuckerberg jumps at the opportunity. Zuckerberg enlists the financial help of Saverin and begins to build thefacebook based on the Winklevoss' idea. Thefacebook becomes an instant success and Zuckerberg is rocketed into stardom. Soon he is entertaining the likes of Sean Paker, Napster founder, and before long is the target of multiple lawsuits.    Of course we all know the success of Facebook and the great drama that surrounds its founders. Still, I was never fully aware of its development and the possible corruption in its founding. The movie portrays Zuckerberg as emotion-less and obsessed with being noticed by the \\"in\\" crowd even if it means sacrificing his only friends. The film bounces between his legal battles and the history of Facebook which took a bit of getting used to but I think that it worked. The acting is excellent and though Zuckerberg doesn't come off as being such a great guy, the movie does solicit some sympathy for him.    I think that this is an important movie not justbecause the script is tight, the acting is excellent, and the subject matter is timely, but also because the influence that Facebook (and Zuckerberg) have had on society is tremendous. Six years ago, no one would ever have thought that the word \\"friend\\" could be turned into a verb or that one could experience someone else's party or vacation by sitting on their own couch hundreds of miles away. Now someone can \\"friend\\" another person or be \\"defriended\\" and pictures can be uploaded to facebook so that people you're not even friends with can comment on pictures of your birthday. It's a kind of revolution that we still don't fully understand and possibly won't for many years. Still, this film reminds us that Facebook is just another website and therefore just another business laden with growing pains and legal troubles. While it did, for a second, make me want to deactivate my facebook (my sentiments were shared by my friend who went to see the film with me) I don't think that's the point of the film. Its message is not anti-facebook but merely proves that it is not God's gift to man. Instead, it was created as a means to distract Zuckerberg from his breakup with his girlfriend and which in turn has helped to distract over 150 million from around the world.

B000NVIXFK|4.0|It's been a long road for Rush since the early 1980s.  All Rush albums, even the worst (1987's \\"Hold Your Fire\\" and 1996's \\"Test for Echo\\") have had at least one good track (usually the first).  It's been a while, though, since the better part of a Rush album has featured material worth listening to more than once.  \\"Signals\\" (1982), though sometimes maligned by fans for kicking off the \\"synth period,\\" may be one of the bands strongest albums.  \\"Grace Under Pressure\\" (1984) is stronger than most remember.  \\"Power Windows\\" (1985) -- \\"synth Rush\\" to the max -- in fact balances some forgettable tracks with a few surprisingly strong ones.  The late '80s and early '90s, though, were almost totally forgettable.  \\"Presto\\" (1989) didn't offer much other than \\"Show Don't Tell\\" (the opener) and 1991's \\"Roll the Bones\\" again had the fantastic opener (\\"Dreamline\\") and not much else(though \\"Ghost of a Chance,\\" the closest Rush has ever come to soul and jazz, is shockingly good).  1993's \\"Counterparts\\" is celebrated by fans as returning to the band to its hard rock roots.  This is true.  In terms of pure songwriting, however, the album didn't offer much beyond \\"Animate,\\" \\"Stick it Out\\" and \\"Cut to the Chase.\\"  By the time they arrived at \\"Test for Echo\\" (1997), it was tempting to think the band was creatively finished.  And, indeed, the band was forced into a hiatus because of the death of the drummer's daughter and wife.  The band's comeback was \\"Vapor Trails\\" (2002).  It was a new Rush; the sound lacked angular prog rock edges  and individual vituosity seemed lost behind a heavy wall of sound.  The heaviness was not totally unwelcome, however.  \\"Vapor Trails\\" held a metal punch generally absent since works like \\"2112\\" (1976).  The album may also have broken some ground in terms of melodic explorations and tonal spectrums.    \\"Snakes and Arrows,\\" however, is the Rushiest Rush album since \\"Moving Pictures\\" (1981). It is also the album most willing to touch on the metal/prog rock/art rock blend that has been at the heart of the band since \\"12.\\"  Indeed, between the two albums, \\"Moving Pictures\\" is the more sophistocated; songs like \\"Red Barchetta\\" simply represent, along with pieces by Yes, King Crimson and Pink Floyd, some of the most sophistocated songwriting and musicianship in rock since the genre became serious art in the 1960s.  Nonetheless, there's a connection to the dark side of the metal movement present in \\"12\\" that has always meant something to the band's sound. The victory of \\"Snakes and Arrows\\" is to take elements from both of those albums and make them relavent again in the twenty-first century.  Not all tunes are winners.  But while not a concept album, \\"Snakes and Arrows\\" tells some kind of story.  And it does so with the polished, inventive and unique musicianship that makes you point at your stereo and say, \\"Now that's RUSH!\\"  With the dirth of real prog rock on major labels, that's a pleasure to say.    \\"Far Cry,\\" the album's opening track, is an out and out Rush tune.  If perhaps not quite as memorable as \\"Tom Sawyer\\" (what, after all, is?), \\"Cry\\" sits together with \\"Sawyer,\\" \\"Animate,\\" \\"Spirit of Radio\\" and \\"Subdivisions\\" as one of the group's truly great anthemic tracks.  Lightening drum fills, good lyrics (often a hit and miss proposition with Rush) and (quoting a Rolling Stone article) a \\"stallion groove,\\" \\"Far Cry\\" is a topical tune that uses 1970s instrumental virtuosity to create a 21st century sound.  It's the band at its best. \\"Far Cry\\" embodies a long career which may, in fact, be coming into a whole new phase.    This simultaneously pointing fowards and back characterizes much of the rest of \\"Snakes and Arrows.\\"   Totally undanceable yet somehow intriguingly odd time signatures were long a band signature, and they return (among other places) in \\"Faithless.\\"  This tune will have junior guitarists and bass players sitting in their bedrooms with sheet music counting eighth notes.  One also gains a touch of the surprisingly beautiful melodicness of the group (think \\"Red Barchetta,\\" \\"Something for Nothing\\" or \\"The Analogue Kid\\").  Indeed, the bass/drum groove at the tune's start and its shift to driving guitar in another time signature might mark some of the band's best musical work in a couple of decades.  It's another victory of blending the old and the new.    Both fans and casual listeners will recognize that Rush always had a little of the \\"rock became serious when longhairs started saying important things with acoustic guitars\\" dimension to them(the same impulse permeating the folksy side of Zeppelin).  It's nice to hear that dimension of Rush return a bit with Alex Lifeson's acoustic ode, \\"Hope.\\"  Lifeson is an interesting guitarist.  If one combs the Rush oeuvre, one finds songs in which he's every bit the match of latter-day guitar heroes like Eddie van Halen, Steve Vai or Joe Satriani.  But Lifeson often diminishes himself; since the end of Rush's first heavy period in the '70s and early '80s, Lifeson has offered few solos or improvisations.  This has  been to the detriment of many Rush albums.  \\"Hope\\" is not an acoustic masterpiece in the rock genre.  It's pretty, though, and skilled.  One gains a sense of rock history and appreciates Lifeson as a guitarist with direct power and prosaicness.    For those who worship Niel Peart -- and that's almost all who have ever held a drumstick and thought that rock was their thing -- one almost starts every new Rush track anticipating what kind of dizzying, near-incomprehensible Olympian fills the master of the massive drum kit is going to throw in .  That makes it sometimes difficult to admit that songs like \\"Animate\\" succeed in part because Peart pulls back from complexity in favor of simplicity.  Such is the case with \\"We Hold On\\" -- a rare track buried at the tail end of a Rush album that absolutely rocks.  Rythmically simple while muscularly prog, \\"We Hold On\\" features the band reflecting a bit on its own legacy as well as that of any who have made something work collectively over a number of decades.  Peart once again delivers good lyrics; crisp Rush playing on the less complex end of their spectrum makes for a tune you'll flip to again and again.    The album's two instrumentals, \\"Malignant Narcissism\\" and \\"The Main Monkey Business,\\" are good. \\"Malignant Narcissism\\" is especially tasty. The tune is all Rush instrumental -- fast, intense, hot licks and great tonalities.  \\"Malignant Narcisissm\\" is every bit as good as \\"YYZ, just minus the hot Lifeson solo.  \\"The Main Monkey Business\\" brings fewer pyrotechnics but a convincing latter-day prog atmosphere.    Among the other tracks, \\"Bravest Face\\" represents particularly strong songwriting -- and there, in the midst of an interestingly folky manifestation of the Rush sound, one gets Lifeson spinning some suprisingly strong solo riffs.  Other tunes, \\"Spindrift,\\" \\"Good News First\\" and \\"The Way the Wind Blows\\" offer some excellent grooves and moments.  In this listener's opinion, however, those songs don't always hang together or represent great listening through to the end.  \\"Armor and Sword\\" is heavy and grows on you.  That growing takes some time, however.  And, unfortunately, \\"The Larger Bowl\\" represents one of the too frequent phenomena on recent Rush albums -- a totally vanilla song that should have been left next to the recording studio mixer.    Can one say that Rush was ever gone?  Revisiting any of their greatest hits albums will remind listeners that while Rush is a band with more than a few utterly forgettable songs (most of \\"Hold Your Fire\\" or \\"Test for Echo,\\" for example), the group also has some of the incomparable moments in rock history.  \\"Tom Sawyer,\\" \\"Red Barchetta,\\" \\"Xanadu,\\" \\"Freewill,\\" and \\"The Trees\\" may not be totally unique, but along with more recent classics such as \\"Dreamline\\" and \\"Animate,\\" Rush can make your jaw drop and force you to admit that one simply has to give it up for a band that won't stop rocking.Nonetheless, for either hardcore fans or the general rock afficianado, it's been a long time since Rush has produced an album one could listen to from start to finish with total satisfaction.  One can discuss whether or not \\"Snakes and Arrows\\" is 100% that album.  It's darn close,however -- and if you take rock seriously, this is an album that deserves a place in your collection.
B004BSIJ9Q|5.0|So, back when `808's and Heartbreak' was dropped everyone and their mother was raving about it as one of the better, more experimental rap albums of all time.  It just didn't sit right with me.  I think I gave it an overall C-grade and I stand by that, despite the fact that `Heartless' is still a pretty great song.  With that in mind, I wasn't too keen on jumping all over `My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy'.  When you combine my thoughts on his last album with my thoughts on his persona in general you kind of have a recipe for disaster.<br /><br />I just don't like him.<br /><br />That said; I was blogging today with some friends and I came across a thread dedicated to this album and I read a few raves that got me interested in picking this up (SALE!!!) and giving it a spin.  I was so intrigued by the brilliance of the albums opening track that I decided to live blog my initial reaction to the album track for track.<br /><br />Here is my post:<br /><br />\\"So I just listened to `Dark Fantasy'...great opener...I was iffy about this album, but it seems to be a step back into better territory for West, that is, if the opening track is really any indication.<br /><br />My interest is peaked...onto `Gorgeous'.<br /><br />So, just finished `Gorgeous'...I thought that the grungy feel would be a turn off, but it really grew on me...I liked the muffled old school rock vibe, and West's rhymes are sharp this go around.<br /><br />Now, onto `Power' (seriously, I've only heard this song once, a live performance on some award show I think)...<br /><br />Why is it that Kanye's arrogance, while so offputting on his actual persona, translates so well into a song? `Power' is great. I especially love the ending, which took the whole track up a notch for me.<br /><br />As I'm typing this I'm listening to the Interlude for `All Out Of Lights'...it's rather beautiful.<br /><br />I didn't expect this from Kanye...and I totally know that this post is going to get ridiculous if I keep updating it after I listen to every track, but I already started and I don't know if I can stop myself.<br /><br />I'm kind of conflicted on `All Of The Lights'...it's a little uneven and kind of chaotic and I can't tell if I like that or if it is a deterrent. Rihanna is superb as usual, and the first part of the bridge is great, while the second part (that female rap stint) is a little off for me. I can't take Kanye 'auto-tune' and he kind of goes there a tad in verses, but overall I like the song.<br /><br />I'm halfway through `Monster' and it is already my favorite track on that album.<br /><br />O<br />M<br />G<br />Do I hear Nicki Minaj?  Yes, this track is fricking epic!<br /><br />The guest list on `So Appalled' is insane, and for the most part they all really work well...but the sum of it's parts is better than the whole, which is kind of uneven and unfocused and I really hate the way they all say 'ridiculous'...I mean, it was like nails on a chalk board after a while...ouch...<br /><br />The vintage, old school R&B musicality of `Devil in a New Dress' was a nice touch, and the mid-song musical interlude of sorts was cool, but the ending guest vocals seemed unnecessary. I mean, I don't get the idea that every song needs to have 'help'...Kanye is more than capable to carry the majority of this album on his own.<br /><br />The 9 minute running time of `Runaway' seems daunting, but so far I'm liking what I'm hearing (it feels like '808's and Heartbreak' only better)...<br /><br />Yeah...9 minutes be darned, the track is pretty stellar...even with the 3 minute (or there abouts) run on at the end.<br /><br />There's nothing really special about `Hell Of A Life', but for an above average generic rap track it works, especially the second half where the musical aspect of the track goes through some nice variations.<br /><br />Ha, ok...'Blame Game' is all sorts of perfection. Even the fact that the track goes from darkly serious to Chris Rock elements of comical, it all works really well...and the piano was a really eloquent touch. Thematically, it's honest and yet it has really great slivers of humor that detach it in all the right places.<br /><br />But seriously, why is there not one normal length track here?<br /><br />Ok, just finished it. `Lost in the World' was odd. The tribal, African theme running through was an odd fit. Totally not my thing, but whatever...good for him I guess.<br /><br />I did like the `Who Will Survive In America' outro though...it kind of laid an obvious context on the album...<br /><br />So, this is just my initial thought here, but this album is pretty genius. The high's are ridiculously high, and the lows are still engaging and listenable...there is not a single `bad' track here...'Monster' may be one of the best rap songs to come out in YEARS!\\"<br /><br />So, I was advised that `All Of The Lights' was one of the best tracks on the album, and so I decided to give it another listen.  I still feel slightly conflicted, but I will say that the second go around definitely has me leaning towards the `it works' side of things.  It is notably flawed, but there are parts of this song that are glimmers of sheer brilliance (especially the musical arrangement that pounds the background).  I'm pretty confident that after a few more listens I'll see what everyone else does.<br /><br />I'm almost there.<br /><br />Oh, so, in case you need me to spell it out for you:<br /><br />B-U-Y T-H-I-S A-L-B-U-M B-E-C-A-U-S-E I-T I-S B-R-I-L-L-I-A-N-T!t places.     But seriously, why is there not one normal length track here?    Ok, just finished it. `Lost in the World' was odd. The tribal, African theme running through was an odd fit. Totally not my thing, but whatever...good for him I guess.    I did like the `Who Will Survive In America' outro though...it kind of laid an obvious context on the album...    So, this is just my initial thought here, but this album is pretty genius. The high's are ridiculously high, and the lows are still engaging and listenable...there is not a single `bad' track here...'Monster' may be one of the best rap songs to come out in YEARS!\\"    So, I was advised that `All Of The Lights' was one of the best tracks on the album, and so I decided to give it another listen.  I still feel slightly conflicted, but I will say that the second go around definitely has me leaning towards the `it works' side of things.  It is notably flawed, but there are parts of this song that are glimmers of sheer brilliance (especially the musical arrangement that pounds the background).  I'm pretty confident that after a few more listens I'll see what everyone else does.    I'm almost there.    Oh, so, in case you need me to spell it out for you:    B-U-Y T-H-I-S A-L-B-U-M B-E-C-A-U-S-E I-T I-S B-R-I-L-L-I-A-N-T!

B000N4SADC|3.0|Just got myself a copy of Hiromi Uetara's Time Control. Got turned on to her by a muso friend of mine. Saw a few clips on Youtube and went mad about her. Specially 'Place to be' ... [...]. Amazing discipline combined with wonderful expressive ability. All too often, people who have undergone such rigorous training have the expressive stuffing knocked out of them. So many such musos end up drowning in technique and become deeply boring as a result. And of course the cliche of Japanese life is that it so conformist that it shrivels the creative impulse like a dried prune. All the more enticing then to see someone like Hiromi cutting up the keyboards and playing her heart out. Beautiful to watch. Having said that, however, I found I couldn't wade my way through Time Control in a single sitting. That's why I only gave it 3 stars. I don't retract anything I said about her - she is a wonderful musician and a great musical personality - but I think she is still young as a composer. In the end I found the pieces tiring to listen to. It's always risky getting a bunch of crack journeymen in a room and letting them rip. They've just got too much to prove. Unless you can rein it in, things can rapidly end up disappearing up the old fundamental. As they all too often did with the early jazz rockers such as Mahavishnu. So many notes, so little time. 0316172324|5.0|Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking by Malcolm Gladwell is an influential book that analyzes the decision making process in humans. The first part of the book deals with unconscious decision making. The book thoroughly describes the experiment done by a psychologist. He records the conversation of couples and can tell if they are going to be together in a few years or not. The psychologist analyzes different reactions of the partners and can tell if everything is right or something is going wrong. By doing this study for a long time he has come up with \\"four horseman\\" that can give information about a relationship. They are defensiveness, stonewalling, criticism and contempt. Even by listening to a couple's conversation for 30 seconds he can tell if they are going to make it or not.  It is also important to stress the fact that none of the partners know themselves how they react.  Then the author goes in more detail on unconscious decision making. The author believes that sometimes we are better off by making snap decisions then making decisions based on too much information. He uses the example of The Pentagon strategy game to illustrate this idea. The Blue Team representing United States that had an enormous system of information and The Red Team representing a rouge country that was very limited in information and communication. Despite these differences, the Red Team won because they used snap decisions made in the field while the Blue team was lost in the huge amount of information it had. Oftentimes  we believe that what we think is free will but in fact it is our unconscious that is doing everything for us.  As the author says : \\" Much of the time we are operating on automatic pilot.\\"  Then the Gladwell also talks about the downs side of quick judgment. We often judge people by their appearance and this can lead to a wrong conclusion. Warren Harding was a tall dark skinned man that imposed authority and respect. People voted him to become presidentof the United States because of these attributes while overlooking other most important elements required in a president. He came to be one of the worst presidents in the United States history.   Up to this point the author seemed to be contradicting himself. Should we trust our gut feeling or not?  Our first impressions may seem that snap decisions come from nowhere, but in fact our unconscious is making these very fast decisions based on our experience and on the environment we live in. By changing our experiences we can change our first impression judgments. So the core idea of the book is that we should trust our snap decisions and that experience improves our instant thinking. We should often make decisions based on our first impressions if we have a good amount of experience.
0307454541|5.0|Great book to read.  You can't put it down until you find out what happens to the characters.  The story is addicting and throws you through so many loops which keeps you guessing until the end.
B000002GJH|5.0|For those who thought Audioslave was powerful, Temple of the Dog just blows it out of the water.  If you think Cornell did his best on lighter songs in Audioslave, well you haven't heard nothing yet.  It's a shame that this record isn't quite well known, but it's an absolutely powerful and soaring record.  Like the other originating bands from Seattle, Temple of the Dog is yet another workable alternative to Prozac, and features real emotion, real catharsis, and a real uplift that their millions of imitators don't have and never will.<br /><br />You probably know the story about this record right now.  Mother Love Bone's singer Andrew Wood died from a drug overdose and many of his fellow Seattle friends were devastated.  Temple of the Dog was a one shot deal featuring Soundgarden's Chris Cornell on vocals and Matt Cameron on drums, with Pearl Jam's Mike McCready, Stone Gossard, and Jeff Ament on Guitars.  Unlike the problematic Audioslave, the combo here pretty much meshes together well and naturally, creating a sound that, predictably, blends elements of Pearl Jam and Soundgarden.  Fortunately though, this record just doesn't sound like a second rate Perl Jam or Soundgarden, as it sounds totally natural in mixing and like a whole different band as it is.  Don't worry, if you like either band, you'll probably like this as well, just don't forget you're not getting merely a mish-mash of Pearl jam and Soundgarden.<br /><br />So what do you get in this record?  Well for one, Chris Cornell.  A few years ago, I would have cringed at the thought of this man taking a place among the best rock vocalists I've ever heard. Now, it's always incredible to hear to his voice, and at his prime few rock vocalists can match him to my ears.  This is one of his primes.  His voice is nothing short of AMAZING here.  He doesn't get as in your face with pure attitude as he does with Soundgarden, but other sides of him that you never thought possible.  He still uses that amazing banshee howel of his (though in a more traditional way than his venom sparked piercing screams of Soundgarden), and he sings absolutely amazing, as it's filled with life, is incredibly soulful, and full of dyanamic range.  And get this, he sometimes pairs the former with the latter!  The hype for his singing is no hyperbole.  Cornell is the main star of this record, and he relishes every moment of it and demands attention. Listening to this almost makes me wishes there was a time machine to get the early Cornell and sing the Audioslave songs at the time he mead this.  Imagine what Show Me How To Live would sound with Cornell on the microphone in the early 90's.  But I digress.<br /><br />The rest of the band itself do not slouch, and they are all great.  Matt Cameron is a much better drummer than Pearl Jam's original drummer, and while he's more subdued, he still has chances to shine with the pounding and glorious drumming or Reach Down, the interesting and groovy intro of Wooden Jesus, and the liveliness of Your Savior and Pushing Forward Back.  Pearl Jam's guitarists seem to play with a bit more focus than they did on Ten, and while it's nothing spectacular, they unleash great riffs and solos (barring some of the unfocused noodling in Reach Down), adding beautiful textures and snaky, great guitar riffs.<br /><br />This isn't quite a perfect record.  The ballads are absolutely jaw dropping as you might expect, although I have to admit, the rockers, while being excellent, don't nearly come close to the former (this comes from the fact that Pearl Jam is probably my least favorite of the seminal Seattle bands, though there great don't get me wrong).  And Reach Down starts absolutely amazing, but it does lose focus during the jam.  Still, these petty complaints don't stain the record. The score is incredibly high, like ALMOST a full five stars, so it doesn't matter much anyway.  Needless to say, this record is EXTREMELY impressive.  If you call yourself a fan of either Soundgarden, Chris Cornell, or Pearl Jam, and you haven't heard this yet, then what is the matter with you?  If it's the last album you buy and you're one of the above, then make it this one., and you haven't heard this yet, then what is the matter with you?  If it's the last album you buy and you're one of the above, then make it this one.

0393072231|5.0|This book is about the unrestrained greed of the financial services industry and Wall Street firms in particular.  Intially, Lewis tells us that his ealier work Liar's Poker created a rush of graduating college students wanting to join the \\"B.S.D's\\" of that book.Contrary to his intent, greed filtered his criticism making it a how-to-manual.     Despite the single mindedness of the banks, 10-20 individuals identified the impending crash of the adjustable rate subprime mortgage based bonds and CDO's. They were either outsiders to Wall Street, or followers of Greg Lippman a trader at Deutsche Bank(an insider company) who viewed himself as an outsider.  Among those we meet are Steve Eisman, Michael Burry, Eugene Xu, Charley Ledley, Jamie Mai and Meredith Whitney. Lewis uses their story as a framework for telling us who the bad guys were...and he does name names...and how they did it.      Lewis distinguishes between the earlier fixed rate subprime mortgages originated by private finance companies in the 1990's and the adjustable rate subprime mortgages of ten years later.  The banks learned from the mistakes of the earlier companies.  The finance companies went public, then bankrupt. The portion of the fixed rate mortgages they kept in-house defaulted.  Shareholders paid the price.    Beginning with Salomon Brothers in 1981, investment banks converted from partnerships to public corporations.  Once the former partners no longer had their own capital at risk, the greed superheated.  Risk passed to stockholders and to investors.  With huge fees and bonuses at stake, the banks gamed the ratings firms into AAA ratings for the adjustable rate subprime mortgage bonds and CDO's they packaged and sold.  Moody's, Standard & Poor's and Fitch knew they were being manipultated but it wasn't until much later that their ratings model started to change.  Once it became known that would happen, investment banks went into hyperdrive to get product out under the old ratings model.      The banks gamed investors.  By increasing the complexity of the derivatives banks made it more difficult for investors to penetrate the CDO's and derivatives...for them to know what they were buying.  With no historical record for the performance of the adjustable rate mortage based bonds and CDO's, investors relied on the word of the salesmen and traders.  By using teaser rates and the purchase of mortgage originators, investment banks were able to accelerate the creation of product for sale to investors.      Eisman and others repeatedly questioned their perceptions of product risk in the face of investment bank assurances that the derivatives were fail safe.  Attendance at industry conferences and an interview with Bear Stearns legend Alan \\"Ace\\" Greenberg were efforts to answer the question:  what do the sellers know that we don't know. The answer is found in the high fees investment banks made for origination of adjustable rate subprime mortgage, for creating the bonds and derivatives and for selling product to investors.    An example of the Wall Street disengagement from the market risk is found in a book written by Greenberg-The Rise and Fall of Bear Stearns.  He sat on the Bear Stearns Risk Committee.  He sold his shares in Bear Stearns as the firm became more involved in risky CDO's.  At one point he tells us how Stearns' President Jimmy Cayne \\"...was one of the few to ever lose a billion dollars in capital\\"  because Cayne had kept his shares until Bear Stearns' forced sale to J P Morgan. Greenberg had sold all of his before the sale.      Convinced of the true risks, Eisman and the others acting independently decided to bet against the bonds and derivatives through the purchase of insurance,a.k.a. credit default swaps.  At first they had trouble finding counterparties since no market existed.  Finally, AIGFP agreed to provide the insurance at a cost of fractions of a penny on the principle dollar amount.  With hundreds of billions of dollars of CDO's and derivatives insured, the millions in annnual premiums were viewed as \\"free\\" money by AIG.  Eisman and the others however felt it was just a matter of time until the teaser rates started to readjust and the defaults started.  Because of the way the CDO's were structured, a default rate of just 8% of the underlying mortgages could make the insurance on an entire individual CDO collectible...and by more than one party.    The excellence of The Big Short is Lewis' history of the suprime mortgage business including the 1990's experience and the meltdown through the interplay of those who saw through the smoke and mirrors so clearly they did not intially believe they understood the market correctly.  Those in the banks who originated the mortgages and packaged and sold the bonds and derivatives were rewarded with tens of millions in payroll fees and bonuses not unlike the 1st people in a chain letter scheme.  Lewis calls them out by name.      In closing the circle back to the theme of Liar's Poker, Lewis relates a recent dinner he had with former Salomon Bros. CEO John Gutfreund after the meltdown.  A small incident with deviled eggs underscores the lack of risk that investment banks had as they packaged and re-packaged derivatives of adjustable rate subprime mortgages.  In Lewis' words: something for nothing never loses its charm.
B00009ZYBY|5.0|Great movie to watch.  It is rich in history and an addictive plot to follow.  You really root for Maximus.
193413712X|5.0|This book is phenomenal. I loved every page...every sentence...every word. Exceptionally well written! The characters are well developed and the plot is fairly unique. It is not an action thriller, it is certainly a \\"slower\\" paced book but I feel in this day and age it's nice to get some rest from our crazy hectic world and find recluse in early woodsy America. This book was not even given a chance in the beginning; it was only through the support of local bookstores that it actually received some attention and now it's a Pulitzer winner! B003Q6D1Z6|3.0|So-would you believe me if I told you that showman P.T. Barnum, in point of fact, never actually uttered the words \\"There's a sucker born every minute\\"? You know how I found that out? I Googled it. It says, right here in the Wikipedia, that P.T. Barnum's \\"famous quote\\" never left his lips. And since I read it on the internet, it simply must be true, right?     In the documentary (-ish) Catfish, a buzz-generating entry at this year's Sundance, directors Ariel Schulman and Henry Joost ask their audience to suspend a lot of disbelief. In spite of a cast billed as playing themselves, and Universal's press kit trumpeting that \\"filmmakers\\" Schulman and Joost \\"...had no idea that their project would lead to the most exhilarating and unsettling months of their lives\\"- well, if this film is a \\"documentary\\"- then I have some beautiful beachfront property in Florida to sell you unseen.     But I could be wrong. Perhaps the events \\"documented\\" in this film did actually transpire as presented, and I'm just an embittered, mean old cynic who has seen too many movies. In fact, let's all play along just for a moment. Let's say that Schulman and Joost really were in the process of making a documentary-in-search-of-a-story, when it struck them that the \\"story\\" was right in front of them the whole time. Schulman's brother Nev, a professional photographer blessed with his own camera-friendly good looks, had struck up a social networking-based friendship with an artistically gifted 8 year old girl from Michigan, who initially intrigued him by snail-mailing strikingly mature oil paintings based on his photos. When the girl's 19 year old sister introduced herself into the mix, Nev struck up a web relationship with her as well; a relationship of a more involved and potentially amorous nature. Inevitably, Nev (now the official \\"subject\\" of his brother's doc) reached a point where he wanted to take the next logical step-and not necessarily for the reasons you might think (sorry about the vagueness; I'm trying to keep this as \\"spoiler-free\\" as possible). Suffice it to say that our intrepid NYC-based trio of dazzling urbanites-turned detectives are soon packing up their film gear and heading to Ted Nugent country for a surprise visit. Ah, but which of the parties involved in this bit of cyber-intrigue is in for the bigger surprise? I could tell you...but then I'd have to kill you.    I do have to hand it to the filmmakers-they have at the very least constructed a virtually critic-proof product. If one decries the possible fakery of the film, then the filmmakers could counter that the heart of the story is, after all, about the inherent deception of cyber romance (the old \\"So how do you know that the hot 19 year old college cheerleader you've been sexting isn't in reality a fat, middle-aged truck driver named Skip?\\" meme). Also, the film is billed as a \\"reality thriller\\"-which could be thrown back at critics as a caveat emptor (\\"Hey-we never exactly claimed that this was a documentary.\\"). Maybe I'm making a mountain out of a molehill, but in a post \\"Blair Witch Project\\" world I feel it is my duty to bring this up. Oh well...wasn't it Godard who said that \\"Cinema is the most beautiful fraud in the world.\\"?     If you can get past the \\"Is it real or Memorex\\" conundrum-this is not necessarily a bad film; it's intriguing enough to hold your interest through to the end. And if the point is to show how we have become a world of Walter Mittys and Eleanor Rigbys, spending the long dark nights of our souls pecking away on our keyboards, busily reinventing ourselves to assuage our lives of quiet desperation, then the film does convey a bittersweet poignancy in the denouement. And I have a confession to make. I don't have any Florida beachfront property for sale.
B00005JNDZ|4.0|Enjoyed this movie.  It is comedic and the cast does a great job of delivering that.  Easy to identify with the characters and situations.
B00427X9WI|2.0|You know, any schlub who has been to at least two world's fairs and a rodeo could have saved the protagonist of this film a lot of time and trouble by quoting Buckaroo Banzai's favorite adage:    Wherever you go, there you are.    Unfortunately for the audience, it takes the globe-trotting heroine of Ryan Murphy's film adaptation of Elizabeth Gilbert's memoir \\"Eat Pray Love\\" 133 minutes to reach that same conclusion (OK, so it took Tyrone Power 145 minutes in \\"The Razor's Edge\\"...but who's counting?)    Julia Roberts stars as Gilbert's avatar in the film, where she is briefly introduced to us as a (seemingly) happy, thirty-something NYC-based writer with a loving and supporting husband (Billy Crudup). I say \\"briefly introduced\\", because soon after a research trip to Bali, during the course of which a shaman (Hadi Subiyanto) foretells that she will lose all her money, but eventually return to study under him so that he may impart his great wisdom, Liz decides that she needs to bolt from the marriage (much to the puzzlement of husband and audience).     While the ink is still drying on her divorce papers (at least in screen time), Liz tumbles headlong into a relationship with a hunky young off-off Broadway stage actor (James Franco). The lust, however, soon turns to wanderlust, and Liz decides that maybe what she really needs is to take a year off from...everything. So, leaving her new relationship somewhere in the neutral zone, she embarks on a three-pronged attack in order to \\"find herself\\", first to Italy (eat), then India (pray) and then Bali (love...oops, is that a spoiler?)    So what does she learn? Want the speed-dating version? Here goes! In Italy, they have like, killer pasta and pizza. Awesome! And the gelato...it's to die for! Oh...and Italians live in the moment, and they talk with their hands...just like the people on Jersey Shore! And when Liz decides to treat her new Italian friends to an all-American style home-cooked Thanksgiving meal with all the trimmings, one of the Italians, being unfamiliar with our ways and customs, forgets to defrost the bird. But, not to worry-Liz puts it in the oven, they all go to bed, and then, they have turkey for breakfast. How whimsical! Next stop: India, where Liz learns piety by scrubbing floors at an ashram. Oh, and gurus live in the moment. Then, it's back to Bali, where she goes back to the shaman who started the whole thing (he lives in the moment). Then, she meets a sexy Brazilian! (Javier Bardem).    Roberts is suitably radiant, flashes her million dollar smile and delivers her patented hearty guffaws right on cue, but she oddly seems to spend a good portion of this (very long) film as an observer of her character's journey, rather than an active participant. Consequently, it's hard for us to really care about what happens to our leading lady; and that is a fatal flaw. The always wonderful Richard Jenkins (as another American at the ashram) briefly perks up the middle third. But as soon as his character disappears, so does the spirit and energy he brings to the film. The locales are gorgeous, and there's plenty of food porn for the gastronomiques, but that doesn't candy-coat Robert's phoned-in performance and the flat, soap opera-ish dialog (co-written by Murphy and Jennifer Salt). It's like randomly surfing between Lifetime, The Food Network and The Travel Channel.    I have not read the source book, nor frankly am I ever likely to. The Pottery Barn angst on display here is tough to sympathize with in these hard economic times (how many of us can afford the luxury of \\"taking a year off\\" to navel-gaze?), and seems bent on perpetrating the Ugly American meme. In fact, I thought that the depictions of the \\"colorful locals\\" encountered by the protagonist on her whistle stops bordered on the kind of colonial stereotyping I assumed Hollywood had abandoned ages ago. You know how they say that \\"It's not about the destination, it's about the journey\\"?  In this case, the trip couldnot be over soon enough.

0061120073|5.0|A Tree Grows in Brooklyn by Betty Smith isn't a novel about a dysfunctional family. It is a lullaby of a quiet corner in the city that never sleeps. It is a lullaby that whispers the joys, hardships, and love of a family that will forever be in my heart.<br /><br />The story revolves around Francie Nolan, a young girl growing up in Brooklyn in the early 1900s. She is one of the only true Americans on her blocks and is proud of it. Living on little food, Francie quenches her thirst for life through books and school. Her mother is a traditional housewife with a twist of rebellion. Her father is a man as magical and loving as he is drunk, living through a kaleidascope of wonder that he teaches his children to adore.<br /><br />Everything about A Tree Grows in Brooklyn was utterly enchanting. I truly connected with each character. It doesn't matter whether you're an eager young author, someone who has experienced a tragic loss, or simply someone who loves life, I believe there is a little bit of everyone in Francie Nolan. Everyone has that childlike need to live their dreams in an attempt to escape an imperfect reality. In fact, all of the Smith's characters are so terrific that it is hard to believe that they are 'ction. Their attitude, togetherness, and love are something that every family should strive to imitate. By the end of the novel, I began to miss the family that I had grown up with as if they were my own.<br /><br />Betty Smith's writing is full of wonderful portraits of the place she grew up. She displays the glory of New York City at a time when immigrants poured into America. Her prose make us feel the pride of Francie's neighbors when they leave their homeland, and the freedom they felt as their boats docked. Yet, along with these beautiful images, she portrays the struggles of so many people living in the small crowded islands of New York City. Betty Smith shows us the loves and losses of a new nation by painting a picture to rival Picasso.<br /><br />The chronicle of the Nolans' life was a truly wonderful and enlightening experience. It is so enchanting to travel alongside the family through their trials and celebrations alike. I will admit to several tear streaked pages and advise anyone who reads this book to have a box of tissues handy. I will end with my favorite part of the book. The tree is growing outside the window as Francie looks out at it for the last time. About the tree, Smith writes: \\"It lived! And nothing could destroy it.\\" Those sentences remind me that nothing ever truly dies. Everything and everyone will live on forever in the memory of all who come to love it.<br /><br />- Victoria Testawas a truly wonderful and enlightening experience. It is so enchanting to travel alongside the family through their trials and celebrations alike. I will admit to several tear streaked pages and advise anyone who reads this book to have a box of tissues handy. I will end with my favorite part of the book. The tree is growing outside the window as Francie looks out at it for the last time. About the tree, Smith writes: \\"It lived! And nothing could destroy it.\\" Those sentences remind me that nothing ever truly dies. Everything and everyone will live on forever in the memory of all who come to love it.    - Victoria Testa

B004BSIJ9Q|3.0|I really don't even know what to say about this.  I may be one of the few people who went into this completely blind.  I had not heard anything that leaked out from this or any of the other songs that people thought would be on here.  So while there are many who are disappointed over specific songs not being on there, or didn't like the ones that were, since they'd heard them already, I didn't have that.<br /><br />I'm a fan of Kanye's music, if not his persona, and was one of the few that actually liked 808 & Heartbreaks, his previous album of autotuned sorrow dealing with his breakup with a longtime girlfriend and the death of his mother.  I appreciated the raw emotion that he put into it and saw it for what it was.<br /><br />Cathartic expulsion of his inner demons and frustrations.<br /><br />This album though, leaves me struggling for words.  I don't know exactly how to describe it, because I don't think I've heard anything quite like it.  It comes off at times like the senseless drunken rantings of a scorned lover, staggering around his apartment, bottle of jack in his hands, as he's screaming about the woman who left him, even after she's already left him days before.<br /><br />There's chunks of the album that don't even feel like fully put together songs, but rather bits and pieces of experimental messing around in the studio.  With 808's, I realized that while it was a complete 180 from anything he had done before, I could understand and appreciate it.<br /><br />THIS....I just lay there listening to the album after purchasing it repeating the same thing over and over: \\"What am I listening to?\\"<br /><br />Even his trademarked lyrical word play, so much in evidence on College Dropout and Late Registration, are virtually gone, replaced by random non sequiters and a bizarre affinity for a Lil Wayne type inflection to his voice on some areas, specifically \\"Power\\".<br /><br />Oddly enough the one standout for the album, if not exactly a hugely positive one, is Nikki Minaj's schizophrenic unleashed verse on \\"Monster\\".  I'd never listened to her before, had never heard her rap or anything.  I'd read about her, mostly negative, but before this had never heard her voice.  I'm not sure if this makes me want to hear more, but it was definitely different.<br /><br />And I will give Kanye credit for once again stepping out of the mainstream of what is expected and completely doing his own thing.  I give him 3 stars for that alone, but I can't do much more than that.<br /><br />I'm still shocked and not sure what the hell I just experienced.  Perhaps this is one of those albums you listen to multiple times and one day you just GET it.  Who knows?  All I know is right now, after listening to it I truly don't get it.<br /><br />I'm starting to wonder whether I'll wake up in the morning and wish I didn't get it, even at the reduced sale price.<br /><br />UPDATE: 3:21pm PST<br /><br />I know some of his fans will not be happy with this review, and judging from the number of \\"not helpful votes\\" I can see that I'm right with that.  However, I think that simply disliking the album is not indicative of my not being a real fan of his music.  I actually think that I'd rather someone be honest and review the album truthfully, then simply throw up a glowing review that was insincere, simply because it might make people upset otherwise, and they'd give my review a negative rating.<br /><br />This is the first album of his that I genuinely did not love as soon as I heard it.  As I said, maybe one day I'll hear it and feel differently, but as of right now it seems like a mess that was rushed out because of all the leaks.  Apparently there's only four songs on here that haven't been released in some form or another over the past year.  Perhaps that played into the final result.<br /><br />UPDATE #2: 12:26am PST (Wednesday the 24th)<br /><br />Looking back I can see that it appears to some that I only have negative things to say about this album.That's not exactly true, so allow me to clarify.  I'd say the first third (give or take) of the album is actually kinda good, and about on par with what I would expect from Kanye.<br /><br />I love LOVE the orchestra and choir aspects on \\"My Dark Fantasy\\" and \\"Power\\".  Those are the things I love the most about his music, and that is his willingness to go outside the realm of hip hop and really showcase his creativity.  It's one of the few things I admired about Puffy back in the day, and him using samples from classical music and rock and pop.  Anything to switch it up and keep people evolving.<br /><br />Yet for all that creativity, somewhere around track 7 is when things seemed to fall apart.  The creativity he had shown on earlier albums (and in spots in the beginning of this one) went haywhire and it seems like it's just a \\"throw stuff against the wall and see what sticks\\" tactic.<br /><br />As I said, I don't know what to make of the album as a whole.  As a whole it's a mess.  In spots it's brilliant and in other spots it's a trainwreck.  I've loved all his other albums, including 808 & Heartbreak.<br /><br />Hopefully that clarified my views a bit.y kinda good, and about on par with what I would expect from Kanye. Dr. Scott even rationalizes how the Original Sin can be attributed to Laziness - a desire for shortcuts to knowledge. Basically no pain - no gain.    He talks of the value of self-discipline - as the tool to fight the pervasive law of entropy, some suffering, of love - as a willingness to extend one self for oneself and for others, meaning taking some effort - is true love. Delayed gratification as part of the multifaceted concept of self-discipline.    Approaches the concept of religion very well, its importance and finally that of Grace. Unwilling to accept change and responsibility (due to at the root laziness) is the source of most psychiatric problems - which have various manifestations - psycho and somatic.     In summary this book cannot be para-phrased or summarized - the book is in itself a summary; which you can expand for the rest of your life's journey. B0038M2AZA|4.0|Claire Danes was a much-heralded actress when she made her major film debut alongside Leonardo DiCaprio in 1996.   Then for a while she seemed to fade into the woodwork.  \\"Temple Grandin\\" is a strong and welcome reaffirmation of Danes' abilities as an actress.    As evidenced by the many reviews here, this is a disarming, straightforward little film about an individual's triumph over disability.  Of course, the message the movie carries is not so much about a misunderstood \\"disability\\" as it is about the simple condition of being \\"different\\".  Midway through the movie we see a large, prominent photograph of Albert Einstein in Temple Grandin's living quarters.  Point taken.  Einstein suffered from epilepsy; he was different.  If you can't appreciate difference, how can you recognize genius?    Temple Grandin has autism, but she is gifted with the ability to instinctively think like an engineer.  She finds a solution to help quiet her problems of anxiety when she visits a cattle farm as a teenager.  Having empathy for the animals, but no understanding of human mannerisms, she elects to pursue a career in animal science.      Much of the movie concerns her struggles to overcome the shortsighted, virulent chauvinism of western cattlemen that she seeks to work with in Arizona.  But, showing an incredible mix of resolve, pluck, and ingenuity, she manages to prevail.    Claire Danes, playing Grandin, keeps a preternaturally alert expression on her face, betraying both fear and curiosity.  Danes also appears to have lost considerable weight to take on the role of a person who subsists on a diet of yogurt, pudding, and jello.   Julia Ormond is luminously beautiful as Grandin's loving and sympathetic mother;  David Strathairn is also effective as a teacher who spots Grandin's intellectual potential.    This movie is a clear winner on all counts, with one minor detraction for me.  The musical score is a stale, numbing take on Philip Glass' minimalism.  Though it may have beenintended to convey a sense of Grandin's inner struggles and determination, I found it instead to be merely irritating.  A minor complaint, but it did affect my appreciation of an otherwise stellar film.

0446195529|5.0|It is a shame that so many people write one star reviews because of the Kindle price without saying anything about the book itself. It is especially shameful when it is about a book that is simply a great read. Baldacci has always given great stories, thrilling books that entertain and at the same time inform.     Hell's Corner is like reading three thrillers in one. His Camel Club stories are tremendous, and this is by far the best yet with strong characters, great plotting and smooth writing that transitions effortlessly. For those who remember his first thriller, \\"Absolute Power\\" and recall how great that was more than a dozen years ago, Hell's Corner is equal if not a bit better, mostly because of several intertwined plots that wind endlessly until the reader might think it can never come together in a logical conclusion. It does, and the end is a most satisfying ride.    I seldom rate books five stars with such enthusiasm, but I really think that Hell's Corner won't disappoint even the most persnickety reader's requirements. If you read only one thriller this fall it has to be Baldacci's Hell's Corner. Ignore the one star complaints - they are justified but there should be other ways of registering their disappointments. I own and use a Kindle often, but for my favorite authors I prefer to have them on one of my bookshelves, and Hell's Corner deserves to be there.

B003XMUFGQ|5.0|Clapton is the latest offering by legendary rock icon, Eric Clapton and a must-have for fans and music enthusiasts alike. Like many classics in the making, this project digs it's hooks deeper into the minds of its listeners each time it's played. While writing this review, I originally wrote \\"rock enthusiasts\\" but changed it to \\"music enthusiasts\\". The reason being is that the CD covers a wide array of genre's that don't really fall into any sort of rock category.<br /><br />The vibe that I get from the album is that I'm sitting in Clapton's living room, being afforded the treat of listening to him jam on a wide range of tunes with friends like J.J. Cale, Derek Trucks, drumming phenomenon, Jim Keltner, Sheryl Crow, Steve Winwood and several others.  From the opening tune, Travelin' Alone, to my personal favorite, River Runs Deep, to Autumn Leaves, you will feel that you're sitting on the outer perimeter of this historic jam session, listening to new, as well as cover, tunes.  You half expects to hear some laughing and cutting up after a song is finished.<br /><br />What I would pay to be a fly on that wall!<br /><br />Clapton's voice is as smooth and strong as ever.  His playing is, well, I mean, c'mon!  We're talking Clapton here!  It's great!  Each note played is fluid and bang on.  Because Eric is playing songs HE wants with no plan or agenda in mind, you get a sense that he's playing from the inner-most being of his heart, creating a love and sincere interpretation to his playing. When a well established artist is able to maintain their love and passion for their music, they (as well as their listeners) are blessed by the experience.<br /><br />This disc is definitely one for your library and will make an excellent gift for the avid music enthusiasts in your life.<br /><br />Randy Patterson<br />Boomerocity.com

B001UV4XHY|5.0|It's hard to believe we've now been living with Harry Potter for going on 12 years for Americans, and 13 years if you're British since the first book was published in the UK as \\"Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone\\" in 1997 and \\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone\\" in the US in 1998. In the first installment of the last book, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part I, the entire Harry Potter enterprise has literally come-of-age. The story and characters have matured along with the writer, her readers/film-goers, as well as the actors in the primary roles. Rupert Grint, Emma Watson, and Daniel Radcliffe in the roles of Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger, and Harry Potter have grown up along with their youthful wizards, and the actors themselves are fast-earning the right to be regarded as A-list talent. Hopefully, they will have fine careers ahead of them, assuming they won't be forever type-cast as the Hogwarts wizard students of the Harry Potter novels. And of course, the ultimate credit of the series belongs to J.K. Rowling who has created a universe as recognizable as JRR Tolkien's Middle Earth, Stephen King's Dark Tower, and Anne Rice's 18th and 19th-century vampire societies.<br /><br />The rest of the cast of \\"HP and the Deathly Hallows\\", aside from the young leads, comprises bona fide A-list actors who were already demonstrating the heights of their craft long before J.K. Rowling was penning Harry Potter in tea shops as a single mother on welfare in Britain. Ironically, the names topping the list play the villains and dark characters: Ralph Fiennes as Lord Voldemort, Alan Rickman as Severus Snape, and Helena Bonham Carter as Bellatrix Lestrange. Special recognition has to be paid to Fiennes as Voldemort whose demonic persona makes the likes of Dracula and Frankenstein's monster appear more like bank robbers by comparison. Fiennes, despite the warped face and absent nose, is entirely believable as the sworn enemy of Harry Potter and an adversary to all that is good in the Wizard World.<br /><br />However the crux of the tale (as with the rest of the series), surrounds the three young leads inside an incredible production. The first couple of installments were written more for a younger age group. Now the characters and their respective actors have grown in complexity and subtlety. They reside inside the skins of their characters in ways which make you believe they understand and appreciate them more. No longer the smart class show-off of younger years, Hermione has grown into a young woman beginning to appreciate more fully the powers she has been taught which can transform the world rather than simply being the most-liked by her teachers. Weasley has a better sense of himself and is now dating Hermione which would have been unthinkable in the first few Harry Potter stories. And Harry Potter is nearing the moment when he can face Lord Vortemort as a near-equal without cringing at the sound of the name.<br /><br />The plot of the present installment is the most complex and compelling yet. Voldemort has gained power over the Ministry of Magic who are running the wizard government akin to Nazism of the 1930's. Anyone with \\"muggle\\" (i.e. non-wizard) blood risks being expelled and/or subdued by high-ranking officials in kangaroo courts. They have even placed a roman-inspired relief in the wizard town square showing muggles being subdued by magic. Although the wizard ministry and government are run by mortal wizards, Lord Voldemort is pulling the puppet strings like a demonic equivalent of the Godfather. He is on the verge of gaining complete immortality through the Horcrux's, amulet artifacts which also have an interesting side-affect of making the wearer become more self-absorbed and selfish, not unlike the Ring of the \\"Lord of the Rings\\". Dumbledore had begun the mission of destroying the Horcrux's as a means of defeating Voldemort; the mission now is passed onto Harry Potter and his friends. Harry Potter along with allies escort him to a refuge but are immediately besieged by the soulless dementors. There must have been a traitor among them which tipped off Voldemort.<br /><br />The three young wizards then engage in a two-fold quest: to obtain and destroy the Horcrux's to stop Voldemort from permanently gaining immortality thereby becoming the absolute-ruler of the Wizard World for eternity. Think of Adolph Hitler wielding a wand. Unfortunately, the Horcrux's appear indestructible, and they must obtain an artifact willed to Potter from the late Dumbledore, a sword, Godric Gryffindor, which Hermione realizes may contain enough power to destroy the Horcrux. During their quest, they keep stumbling upon a strange triangular symbol, which even appears on one of the stones of a cemetery at Harry Potter's birthplace which is also his parents' deathplace.<br /><br />A brilliant and compelling film all the way around despite having been absent from Hogwarts, with absolutely phenomenal effects which neither impedes the story nor hinders the acting but enhances the Wizard World and the story contained within. The acting is some of the best I have seen for a fantasy film/story, it's only rival Peter Jackson's \\"Lord of the Rings\\". The best which can said of this film is that it never appears like the filmmakers were relying solely on the Harry Potter name for success. They have forged a brilliant film to climax the series, one of the best all-time in fantasy-filmmaking.e but are immediately besieged by the soulless dementors. There must have been a traitor among them which tipped off Voldemort. The acting is some of the best I have seen for a fantasy film/story, it's only rival Peter Jackson's \\"Lord of the Rings\\". B003A4IFDW|3.0|Bettye LaVette has been around forever and a day without deserved acclaim until now!  Back in the sixties noticed this great voice but Bettye only played on R&B stations caught this soul music lovers attention and have a number of old stunning 45 rpm's that are classic. Early eighties a great Motown Lp \\"Tell Me A Lie\\" (\\"Right In The Middle Of Falling In Love\\" should have been a smash!) was released and felt certain her time had come...no promotion & minimal airplay resulted in Bettye once again snubbed by the music industry and took years for Bettye to have chance come her way again so unfortunate \\"Interpertations\\" isn't perfection as it should have been.<br />Early nineties stellar release \\"Atlantic Sisters Of Soul\\" featured incredible Bettye LaVette riveting stand-out performance \\"Your Turn To Cry\\" from tremendous unreleased Atlantic Records Lp and believe this started the buzz leading to current success. Surrounded by terrific singers like Mary Wells, Esther Phillips, Dee Dee Warwick and other legendary soulful Divas, Bettye's soul-stirring anthem stands out big-time and what a memorable & hypnotic performance it is! Live sets and great releases lead to current collection which is a mixed bag that I really wanted to love but should have come out better and exceeded expectations but sounds like somebody got way too serious...up-tempo numbers and riveting power ballads with strong rhythm tracking are best suited to Bettye's rough & raw voice yet \\"Interpretations: The British Rock Songbook\\" has a number of slow songs with no rhythm track to carry vocals and these don't work and end up sounding the same...contrast this with riveting Hollywood Bowl \\"Beatle Tribute Concert\\" performance, Bettye took the evening by storm giving a show-stopping performance with a fine full orchestra receiving a well deserved standing ovation from an enraptured crowd...Bettye was stunning and on fire!<br />\\"Interpretations\\" does have its moments of greatness always found in a LeVette set and hot funky opener \\"The Word\\" is a promising start as Bettye makes this one her own while an amazing \\"It Don't Come Easy\\" is another definitive performance that is wildy hot & riveting...\\"No Time To Live\\" is richly engrossing but by now sadly it becomes apparent too many slow lumbering songs with Bettye sounding in too much pain drag things down showing Bettye LaVette is best with strong rhythm tracks and terrific when she funks it up and has some fun! Compare the riveting & passionate Joe Cocker \\"Maybe I'm Amazed\\" from \\"Heart and Soul\\" or the rocking Petula Clark version from \\"Warm And Tender\\" to this bogged-down version and these fiery definitive versions work and are inspired...both legends take Paul McCartney classic to the max and are essential & highly recommended for any music lover who love definitive performances. Remix would be awesome of all lumbering slow songs in this collection to have fired up rhythmic arrangements and \\"Maybe I'm Amazed\\" with a Joe Cocker like arrangement featuring Ms. LaVette would be a winner. Bettye is a tremendous legendary singer deserving a legendary equal like Gamble/Huff Dexter Wansel or Jimmy Jam/Terry Lewis at the helm arranging & producing and results would be extraordinary.  Closing \\"Interpretations\\" with beautifully orchestrated searing live performance \\"Love Reign O'er Me\\" show a live collection would be great for the next Bettye LaVette project but this time give Bettye the support she needs with a brilliantly arranged orchestra complete with a hot cooking rhythm section and inspired background singers...spice it up and have fun! Sometimes an artist can get too serious and results become stiff...sadly looks like that is what happened this time...loosen up & let it flow then next time could be that classic we are waiting for!
